description: From Middle English shire, from Old English scir, from Proto-West Germanic *skÄ«ru.

entries.meaning: Physical area administered by a sheriff.
Former administrative area of Britain; a county.
examples: Yorkshire is the largest shire in England.

entries.meaning: (UK, colloquial) The general area in which a person lives or comes from, used in the context of travel within the United Kingdom.
examples: When are you coming back to the shire?

entries.meaning: A rural or outer suburban local government area of Australia.

verbs.description: shire (third-person singular simple present shires, present participle shiring, simple past and past participle shired)

entries.meaning: To (re)constitute as one or more shires or counties.
examples: Although he still managed formally to shire the province in the summer and autumn of 1585, his plan to establish a presidential government and complete the integration of Ulster into English Ireland met with royal indifference.
